Science can't predict culture, because it's the business of culture to be dynamic and unpredictable, confounding analysis.  
Scientific method was first applied to advertising in the early 20th century (Starch, etc.), but it hasn't gotten any further traction than market research. There you have the tension between reason and intuition.

If it's assumed that someone is going to read the text, then going by the numbers may seem useful. Meanwhile, the reader has caught sight of a page of text and the conditioned response is, "am I going to even bother reading this shit?" (sorry, it's _le mot du jour_).

Nick, I think that readability is part of what makes a text inviting, so it isn't a completely separate issue. Certainly there is a lot more to attracting a reader, and the design can contribute (or detract) greatly from whether people want to read something. Also of course how well written the stuff is makes a big difference as to whether they continue reading, once they start.

Exactly. But why are you assuming that it's only readability if it can be measured?

The readability of a document is dependent on many factors, mostly typographic (those that Jackie mentions), i.e. governed by the layout, not the typeface. In fact, the typography determines the readability of the text to such an extent that it can easily reverse the relative readability of fonts, as measured in the lab.

I don't assume that anything exists only if it can be measured. That's a version of positivism, and I don't share it. If one were measuring readability of extended text, things like measure, typeface and leading would have to be included. I agree with you that these will prove important. But so will type design and letter spacing, IMHO.

"What was wrong with the “exact type” in [the ClearView] study?"

A small group of drivers were then driven around the signs (the 'control of which was a particularly beat-up old Highway Gothic of PA), in a limited number, maybe even two conditions of light and weather, and asked questions. Does a huge x-ht help in all conditions? Is the tailed l always right in distant word shapes? Can and how will composers deal with an un-unitized product after all these years? Does Clearview actually work in all the layouts required with all the changes from Highway Gothic?

Sure something's been studied, but without having ever done anything even remotely similar to this, what makes you think either the studiers or the studyees were even on the right road, much less properly addressing fundamental issues of implementation? I take it then you agree on the MS studies.

Thanks to Thomas for finding the actual study report. Unfortunately the popular press report missed the point of the study. Here is my summary:

In their first study the participants read instructions about an exercise program. The instructions were either written in an easy to read font (Arial 12) or a difficult to read font (Brush 12). The participants who read the instructions in the easy to read font reported that the exercise program would take less time and they would be more likely to take part in the program than the participants who read the instructions in the difficult to read font.

In their second study the participants read instructions about how to prepare a Japanese roll. The instructions were either written in an easy to read font (Arial 12) or a difficult to read font (Mistral 12). The participants who read the instructions in the easy to read font reported that the recipe would take less time to prepare and they would be more likely to try it than the participants who read the instructions in the difficult to read font.

To repeat what I posted on the ATypI list, with a couple of minor edits for clarity:

It turns out the actual studies (there were three related studies) are posted here:  
 [http://sitemaker.umich.edu/norbert.schwarz/files/08\_song\_\_\_schwarz\_effor...](http://web.archive.org/web/20100825012921/http:/sitemaker.umich.edu/norbert.schwarz/files/08_song___schwarz_effort_psychscie_in-press_30apr08.pdf "http://sitemaker.umich.edu/norbert.schwarz/files/08\_song\_\_\_schwarz\_effort\_psychscie\_in-press\_30apr08.pdf")

The first study compared just Arial and Brush Script, used in restaurant menus. The second and third compared Arial and Mistral, used in recipes.

Yes, they found that Arial was more readable than Mistral or Brush Script, but the point was \*not\* to find the most readable font possible. They were trying to manipulate the readability as an independent variable, by using the font. That is, they needed a more readable font and a less readable font, in each study. The dependent variables were the conclusions people would draw about the content being changed by the ease of reading.

So, unless you think Mistral and/or Brush Script are in fact more readable than Arial, folks should not have problems with this study based on their beliefs about the legibility of different typefaces.

Having read the paper, I am reasonably convinced that they succeeded in measuring what they wanted to measure. The results of the first study would have been of dubious by itself, as one could argue that there were other plausible causes for the experimental outcome, which would be a result of the font but not based on simple difficulty of reading. But the second and third studies lead to a reasonably strong conclusion that their theory is correct.

Cheers,

T

"Does anybody actually \*READ\* these studies before criticizing them at great length based on bizarre snippets of media coverage?"

Of Course. Do you?

KL: "...typeface selection is important....

_But it’s not._

You don't say.

_unless you think Mistral and/or Brush Script are in fact more readable than Arial,_

What David said.

David, I haven't read the full studies on Clearview, but in the New York Times article they mention that they drove people toward the different signs in daylight and at night with headlights and noted at what distance they could read the names on the signs. And there were quite significant differences in the distances.

I think I remember reading some report summaries also to this effect, but I don't have the links at the moment.

This kind of test seems pretty good to me, if carried out with proper controls.

Actually, DB's comment is pretty meaningless.

The study was not trying to show that Arial was universally easier to read than (whichever script font). Just to study the effects of varying the ease of reading.

It's utterly irrelevant to these studies if one could vary other controlled variables, to make the script faces harder to read than the Arial. The question is, were they correct in their claim that under these particular conditions, Arial was easier to read? Their study seemed to show that was true, as a preparatory point towards looking at the effects of this.

Now, there are other points of these studies worth critiquing. Could all the effects of the study been the effects of a more ornate/fancy typeface rather than ease of reading per se? If their conclusions were correct, one could repeat the study by using \*only\* Arial, and creating the "harder to read" condition by setting Arial at 6 or 7 point.

Cheers,

T

\>Actually, DB’s comment is pretty meaningless.

It pains me to see the help be rude to Berlow when he is the only person of real distinction in the type industry who contributes to Typophile. I'm a very rude person but I would never dare be rude to David. Admittedly he can be difficult to understand, but what sage isn't? Like many, every sentence he writes has got a whole paragraph, a whole page, a whole book behind it.

As far as I know, there has never in the entire history of type been a legibility study that would stand up to scientific scrutiny. The reason is that legibility problems have always been satisfactorily solved by people like Benton, Griffith, Carter, and Berlow.

_Which of the Microsoft type studies do you rank as the absolute ’top of the class’?_  
I’ll defend all of them if you’ll read them first.

_I could change one variable, (the sizes), and prove the Selection of Mistral over Arial. (I could also quite likely upset the results with exactly the same specimens they used.... by collecting a different extraordinarily small and narrowly aged audience!?_

First, Thomas’ comments are spot on that this is completely irrelevant to the point of Song & Schwarz's study. They were demonstrating that the perception of the font impacted the perception of the content. The specific fonts involved did not matter.

Second, you misunderstand how the scientific method works. Say for example that you’re right and you can change Mistral in some way, and you find that people thought that the exercise program would take less time. Does that invalidate the results? No. It extends the results and is exactly what should happen. Is there some narrowly aged audience that responds in a different way? That would be interesting to know too. That’s another extension.

Song & Schwarz tested a theory and learned something about how readers respond under the specific conditions they defined. There is always more to be learned, and by writing a report about what they learned, they invited others to participate in the process. Everyone (including DB) is now welcome to run their own studies with 30 point Mistral on 14 year olds to better understand the reading experience.

Bill, is it really required that you refer to somebody as the "help"? To me this denigrates whatever points you make afterwards.

I make this point for a variety of reasons but the most important one is this: when a 3rd party has wades through Typophile discussions in search of an answer to a question they are interested in, or perhaps who thinks what on whatever topic, there ends up being a lot of chaff with the wheat when personal stuff is involved. Some of that is inevitable. But a lot of it isn't. I would sooner see Typophile be a more rather than less useful for us all.

And really it would be good if we all kept that in mind - not just Bill.

Thanks!

_Say for example that you’re right and you can change Mistral in some way, and you find that people thought that the exercise program would take less time. Does that invalidate the results?_

Perhaps not, but it would still be a meaningless experiment.

This is a mistaken project from the get-go, designed to answer the question "if we make something hard to read, will people think it describes something that's hard to do?" But the actual test measures nothing of the sort.

What if ease of "legibility" or "readability" has nothing to do with this? What if there is some other visual cue in typeface selection, such as, oh, I don't know, something a typographer might think of? Might it not be that a large x-height sans serif face communicates "efficiency", while a script type says "slow down and smell the roses"? What have these typographic qualities got to do with the "ease with which...information can be processed"?

"I’ll defend all of them if you’ll read them first.  
I read plenty, but it's no longer on my agenda. With MS spending $1/2 billion to re-market Vista, I know.

"They were demonstrating that the perception of the font impacted the perception of the content. "  
The perception of a child's _font specification_ impacted the perception of the content to children.

"Actually, DB’s comment is pretty meaningless."  
All of what you say goes on to more type specification, not selection. One is a subset of the other, and you cannot make a meaningful decision on style, without making a decision on size, (at LEAST).

This study made no meaningful contribution to what I know about type specification or selection. That being the case, I assure you anyone who learned from this is learning in the rong direction. Nothing personal, my mom went to Michigan, and I drew MS's Mistral.

Cheers!

_Might it not be that a large x-height sans serif face communicates “efficiency”, while a script type says “slow down and smell the roses”?_

Excellent, that’s another possible direction to extend these results. Thomas suggested comparing different sizes of Arial; or you could make two matching fonts that only differed in x-height. Either would be a way of looking at size differences without differences in type style. This extension does not make the original study mistaken or invalid in any way. If the extension provides a better interpretation of the results, people will adopt the better interpretation.

_This study made no meaningful contribution to what I know about type specification or selection._

Good, because this study was not about type specification or selection. This was about demonstrating that the perception of fonts impact the perception of content. I did find it surprising and interesting that people thought the same exercise program would be easier when they read about it Arial. Imagine that former Bush administration official is writing an autobiography and they want to appear more sympathetic and likable. Can a particular font choice help?

What clearly dissatisfies some of us is how incremental and simple the results of these tests can be. We know the result before it's revealed. But there also seem to be a number of tests with flawed questions at their root, such as "is my new font, designed specially for the blind, that I'm getting school credit for, more readable than an intricate, curlicued display font?" The result might have integrity (why yes, this simple font based on Comic Sans is more readable than that scratchy, ambiguous display font), but the test itself doesn't; it's a foregone conclusion, and the design of the test is manipulated to give the desired result. Those tests are specious because they aren't objective, **and** they ask irrelevant questions.

However, Nick and David, while I know what you know, and we know it, and it apparently is going to take until 2168 to accumulate enough empiric data to confirm it scientifically, what Kevin has said holds true: if an experiment asks a very simple question, and I'm sure you'll agree it's difficult to design these tests, we can actually get meaningful results. But the meaning and the import of the results is likely to be much more satisfying and consequential to someone who doesn't design type all day. It doesn't make the test false, or the question wrong, or the whole thing a load of poppycock, if we find the result boring or predictable.

Kevin is not disputing that it may be more interesting or revealing if we test other variables, like size and contrast and all the niceties that go into reading. But we're throwing the baby out with the bathwater if we dismiss every finding because it isn't sophisticated enough for us. Once a number of these results are assembled, a more nuanced and specific test can be designed that includes those parameters and takes into account the results already discovered. That's the scientific method. Reading is very complicated, and so many factors affect it, that of course it will take a long time for all those variables to be understood. Each one has to be isolated in a large testing situation and clear differences have to be demonstrated. Then there are the thousands of typefaces, the choice of which inevitably rubs people the wrong way.

Kevin, I think what is dissatisfying, over and above the slow, rudimentary progress in this area, is that here on Typophile, where type designers hang out, we often hear of these tests and ask, "Why didn't they consult a typographer or type designer?" Whether the testing is flawed or fierce, We hear about it after the fact. We can actually effect more speedy, substantial progress in this area if we are included in the process of designing these studies, but apparently we're invisible.

_Can a particular font choice help?_

This is the kind of thing that graphic designers do for a living.  
I'm shocked you have been working closely with type for several years and have no idea how it is used professionally.

"This was about demonstrating that the perception of fonts impact the perception of content."  
Okay... name me the variables of how fonts impact the perception of content Kevlar.

You're seeing a demonstration that the use of bad selection and bad composition impacts the perception of content. The other comments that are made in the linked story, reinforce the bad turns/learns of this study.

Proper scientific method in type design, _gives you selection_, it's 'our' job to understand (and design) all the details involved in a careful dance with perception of content, including some that the guys and gals in the Michigan Business School might overlook from simple, honest, ignorance, **an excuse not available to professionals in the type business, _I'm afraid_**.

The type design method for developing the study we're discussing would be:  
1. Compare Arian to Arial at the same size from the same device on the same paper. Skip the expected 50-50 results and change something.  
2. Compare Arial to Mistral. Okay, you've made your one mistake, Arial has an inbred familiarity and Mistral not so much and definitely not for the desired perception of simplicity required of instructions for cooking or Ikea. If you make the mistake of not evening the x-heights, you are no longer testing perception of content. Period.  
3. If you even out the x-heights, both fonts are legible, and you get correct results, (probably 70-30), and you learn

Font selection impacts the perception of content, but if your composition has removed legibility. . . don't bother me with insisting on correctly testing perception of content.

When one says something like this:  
"The easiest to read is the Arial (font)," Song said.  
...think on that: based on two fonts, and 25 or so late-teenage reactions, sound like type science to you?  
I said before they learned nothing, what I should have said is they learned how to get attention at the expense of type and science in one swell foop.

Cheers!

_Kevin, I think what is dissatisfying, over and above the slow, rudimentary progress in this area, is that here on Typophile, where type designers hang out, we often hear of these tests and ask, “Why didn’t they consult a typographer or type designer?” Whether the testing is flawed or fierce, We hear about it after the fact. We can actually effect more speedy, substantial progress in this area if we are included in the process of designing these studies, but apparently we’re invisible._

I agree that this is a problem. Obviously whenever I talk to psychologists or anyone interested in studying typographic variables, I do my best to educate them about the field of typography and to get them to meet and talk to the typographers here (Mike Duggan and Geraldine Wade). But that is an incredibly small percentage of reading psychologists. Somehow we really need to get to a state where typographers and reading psychologists interact more frequently. Any ideas about how to make the field of typography less invisible?

There's not much that will take the blinkers off the way scientists approach this subject.  
Ideally, reading psychologists could learn typography.  
Have you considered taking a degree in design?  
That would add an edge to your work, and set an example to your peers.

Legibility problems are solved not by scientists, and certainly not by pseudo-scientists, but by a few genius type people who discover ways to put more words on less paper and still have most of us be able to read the stuff without noticing it. The methodological weakness of the Song & Schwarz study is a weakness that is very common in the 'softer' sciences such as psychology and social science. It is that the theory they are testing is not well specified. And as a result it is not clear what lesson to take from the results.

My old teacher Popper used to say that an experiment is only as good as the theory that it is testing. If the theory that is being tested is not clearly and precisely specified, then the chances are that you don't learn a lot from the result.

The problem that typographers such as Nick Shinn and David Berlow are having here is that they know that there are so many more variables involved in readability than typeface. Since Song and Schwartz don't discuss these, it is not very clear what you can conclude from the study.

Also note that they asked about the readability of the typeface \*after\* they had done the reading and got answers on how difficult they expected the task specified would be. This is a problem. I know from doing simple surveys of satisfaction with courses I have taught that if a person likes the course, they are likely to be positive about everything, and if they are negative, negative about everything. The respondents can't necessarily separate out very well what they are responding to.

Also note that people may perceive 'readability' of the simplest sans forms as being most readable, but that perception may be based on impression of individual letters or words, and may not necessarily reflect actually readability of extended text as far as ease, speed and comprehension. The subject guessing is about readability, not giving an objective result.

So with these confounding factors, what they found is only this: post-hoc feelings about typefaces of these sizes, fonts and layout, and post-hoc feelings about ease of task described went together.

So is this a somewhat interesting confirmation that typography matters? Yes. Is it clear exactly what this study means? Not really. Not a great study, and not a dreadful one either. Just so-so.

In my reading, this was not a usual readability test (as is suggested by the unfortunate title). Rather, it aimed at demonstrating that human activities or judgement are influenced by minute aspects that are unrelated to the activity or subject-matter of the judgement and normally go unnoticed. In this case, demonstrate that choice of a typeface (which most of the time is something readers are not aware of) influences whether people consider a task described (recipe set in one or another typeface) as harder or easier to perform.  
In this respect, what you consider confounding is the strength of the test: It does _not_ make participants aware of the minute aspect. This is an essential part of the test. In my opinion, they should not have mentioned typefaces at all in their questions.  
But it would have been more interesting with a more subtle choice of typefaces. Arial and Mistral are so obviously different that participants may have noticed what the test was "really" about even without being told ...
